sentences.q: The navigation instinct is what makes certain creatures, birds and amphibians return _____ the place they consider home.
Cats often have this instinct. It was particularly strong in an American cat called Ninja, which disappeared shortly _____ its owners had taken it to their new home.
A year later the cat turned up at its old home even _____ this was 1,360 kilometres away from where its owners were now living.
Other cats may not travel so far but many _____ on going back to their old home.
Pilsbury, an English cat, made a 13-kilometre journey back to its former home 40 times in spite _____ having to cross several busy roads to do so.
Pigeons also have the homing instinct and, over _____ centuries, human beings have used them to carry messages back home.
However, cat owners, _____ have to keep returning to their old address in order to bring their cat home, tend to find the homing instinct simply irritating.
Cat owners have to keep returning to their old address in _____ to bring their cat home.
Folding bicycles have _____ around for quite some time now.
However, an amazing new Japanese version _____ be folded with a swiftness and efficiency never seen before.
This bike is designed _____ that it is possible to fold it up quickly.
Once folded, you pull the bike along _____ ease.
And, although the basic idea is _____ original, its inventor has created an especially clever variation.
Its inventor has created an especially clever variation, combining compactness _____ convenience with smart design.
Recently, folding bicycles _____ become very popular in Japan, particularly in congested urban areas like Tokyo.
Tokyo is a city _____ every square centimetre of space is in great demand.
In the last few years, a number of cookery schools have been set _____ in Ireland to promote Irish cooking.
One such school is run by Kathleen Doyle not _____ from the centre of Dublin.
'The school was by no means an overnight success; I found _____ necessary to work hard to build up a reputation.'
'One of my advantages was that I'd had problems with my own cooking. I've made every mistake that it's possible to make, but _____ of this, I know what people do wrong from first-hand experience.'
Just _____ most cookery schools in Ireland, Kathleen initially copied the classical dishes of France and Italy.
Kathleen initially copied the classical dishes of France and Italy and other countries _____ have a reputation for excellent food.
'Now though, things are changing,' says Kathleen. 'We get excellent produce from Irish farms and, _____ a result, we're encouraging students to create unique Irish dishes.'
We're encouraging students to create unique Irish dishes _____ reflect our heritage.
It _____ sometimes said that animals use language.
Certainly some animal species have developed amazingly sophisticated ways of communicating with _____ another.
When animals make a sound, such _____ a bark or a call, it is in reaction to what is happening around them.
It is in reaction to _____ is happening around them.
Only human beings are capable _____ doing this.
Zoologists have had some success in teaching human language to animals. _____ some famous experiments, chimpanzees have been taught to use their hands to give information.
In some famous experiments, chimpanzees have _____ taught to use their hands to give information on a range of things.
Some animals have even managed to put signs together in _____ to make simple sentences.
Most authors admit that the brilliant idea, _____ seems to arrive from nowhere and results in a work of genius, does not often come along.
At _____ the blank screen of a computer might appear to offer very little in the way of a good idea.
But some say it eventually works _____.
Others prefer to go jogging, and often return home _____ successfully dreamed up a good storyline.
But there are several less difficult ways to find good ideas for a story. _____ method is to read other people's work.
This may sound _____ a statement of the obvious.
_____ a teacher of creative writing, I am often discouraged when I learn that a student on my short-story writing course has never actually read any short stories!
To write short stories you must read _____ that is currently being published.
Many years ago, when I was nine years old, my parents took me to see _____ a science fiction film.
It had _____ advertised everywhere as the greatest film about space exploration ever made.
I couldn't really understand the story. I thoroughly enjoyed the film _____ it wasn't a problem for me, because I was lost in the photography, the music and the special effects.
'I clearly remember the way in _____ the giant space station on the screen seemed to roll over my head.
I thought its gentle movement against a background of stars was _____ of the most beautiful things I'd ever seen.
I still get tears in my eyes _____ I remember this scene.
The spaceships looked _____ very real that I couldn't believe that they were not, in fact, real.
There was even more impressive photography later on, when the crew of the spaceship went _____ dangerous walks in space.
The kangaroo is an instantly recognisable animal _____ familiar outline is often used as a symbol of its native country, Australia.
Wild kangaroos _____ still to be found in quite large numbers in almost every part of Australia.
They move around on two powerful back legs, with a long, thick tail to keep _____ balance.
In fact, the word kangaroo is used for any _____ about forty-seven different species of animal, all of which belong to the kangaroo family.
All of _____ belong to the kangaroo family and have a similar appearance.
Generally speaking, it is the larger members of the family that are called kangaroos – their smaller relations are more usually known _____ wallabies.
_____ the word kangaroo comes from an ancient Australian language, it is not the word speakers of that language used to describe the animal.

Indeed, according to legend, the animal was given the name as the result of a misunderstanding. _____ the first European explorers saw the strange hopping creature, they asked a local inhabitant what it was called.
Bees are important _____ us not just because they make honey.
They play an important part _____ agricultural production.
They are never found very far from the flowers _____ provide them with food.
Bees spend a _____ of time looking for flowers that contain pollen and the other substances.
When a bee discovers a new source, it can inform other bees of the location of the flowers by _____ a special dance.
The movements it makes tell five other bees _____ far they have to fly and in what direction.
When they are carrying pollen, bees accidentally drop some of it onto other flowers and in this _____ they fertilise them.
Bees are very important for agriculture _____ many plants can only be fertilised by the activity of bees.
With around four hundred seats, a jumbo jet holds as many people _____ a medium-sized hotel or hospital.
On a typical intercontinental flight, passengers are given at least one hot meal, plus snacks. British Airways, in _____, with most major airlines, prepares this food at its home airport.
Its catering centre has a staff of eighty chefs who, each day, prepare meals for flights _____ could feed almost fifty-six thousand people.
Menus are planned on a three-monthly basis, but there are always last-minute changes _____ special diet meals for health, religious or cultural reasons.
These meals can be _____ up to twenty-four hours before departure.
The chefs plan quantities four days in advance, _____ on information from the reservations computer.
Flights may appear fully-booked; chefs will produce meals according to computer predictions of how many seats will actually be _____ on the day.
This is because so many passengers who book seats _____ to turn up.
Charles Dickens was one of the greatest nineteenth-century English novelists. At the time of _____ death in 1870 he was a wealthy man, in contrast to the poverty of his early days.
His parents did _____ best to look after him but were always in difficulties with money.
Two days after his twelfth birthday, Dickens was taken away from school by his parents and made _____ work in a factory in London to increase the family income.
Factories could be dangerous places in _____ days and some employers were cruel.
Charles was not extremely unhappy, but also ashamed of working there, and he _____ never forgot that period of his life.
Years later, in his novel 'Oliver Twist', Dickens described his own childhood experiences. Oliver Twist was one of his most famous characters and he too suffered _____ a child worker.
Dickens' novels showed how shocking working and living conditions _____ and working in the factory affected him so deeply that he found it much too painful to speak about in later life.
His own wife and children knew little about the unhappiness of his childhood _____ Dickens was still alive.
